title: Japan delivery king Yamato looks to India, M&A to triple overseas sales
content:
Group aims to offer business-to-business services in fast-growing market

TOKYO — Leading Japanese ground delivery provider Yamato Holdings aims to triple annual overseas revenue within the next few years and sees India as its top priority for growth.

“We’ll expand the scope of our business while keeping our eye out for M&A deals,” President Yutaka Nagao told Nikkei.

“It’s a country with such growth potential,” Nagao said of India. “It would be a waste to try to expand there on our own.”

Yamato has “found partners with whom we’re able to hold various discussions,” Nagao said.

“We’ll make up-front investments, including setting up multiple warehouses, and combine them with the transportation networks” built by Indian companies, he said.

Yamato expects roughly 150 billion yen ($1 billion) in overseas sales for the fiscal year ending Monday.

The company will shift its growth focus to corporate business, which covers a wide range of logistics operations, such as inventory management and distribution processing for industries like autos and electronics. Yamato aims to grow revenue in Asia and the U.S.

Yamato Holdings President Yutaka Nagao speaks with Nikkei on March 27 in Tokyo. (Photo by Kotaro Igarashi)

India is expected to become the world’s third-largest economy in 2027. The country’s freight and logistics market will reach $545.6 billion in 2030, according to Mordor Intelligence — up more than 50% from the company’s 2025 forecast.

Yamato will raise funds for acquisitions by reviewing assets and reducing cross-shareholdings. The group completed the sale of Tokyo headquarters buildings Friday, switching to a leaseback agreement. Yamato is considering switching to lease contracts for a portion of its delivery vehicles and distribution centers.

Consumers account for 60% or so of the parcels that Yamato handles. Japan’s declining population is pushing the company to grow its business-to-business services.

Meanwhile, the number of collection and delivery centers serving consumers around Japan will be reduced by roughly 40% from the current 2,800 or so. The centers will be consolidated into 1,800 locations by the end of fiscal 2026.

The company’s parcel delivery service has struggled amid a downturn in consumer spending, though the business has shown signs of recovering. In the October-December period of 2024, Yamato’s consolidated operating profit rose 9% to mark its first year-on-year growth in eight quarters.

But Yamato still faces pressure from a trucking-sector labor shortage under new overtime rules and is being squeezed by high fuel prices. To secure enough personnel, “we need price pass-throughs in line with inflation,” Nagao said.

Yamato looks to renegotiate freight prices with large corporations that have been given greatly discounted rates.

“We’ll also upgrade our sales capabilities so that [customers] understand that the prices are fair,” Nagao said.
summary: Yamato Holdings will consolidate its domestic network of collection and delivery centers. (Photo by Kai Ishizaki) Group aims to offer business-to-business services in fast-growing market KAI ISHIZAKI ...

title: With India’s help, Vietnam challenges for Thailand’s tourism crown
content:
Southeast Asia adapts as outbound Chinese travel remains below pre-pandemic levels

David Mann is chief economist for the Asia-Pacific, Middle East and Africa at Mastercard.

Vietnam is aiming for Thailand’s crown as Southeast Asia’s top international tourist destination. And Indian visitors may help it get there.

Thailand still welcomes the most tourists of any Southeast Asian nation, with 35.5 million arrivals in 2024. But Vietnam is the region’s fastest-growing market; its 17.5 million arrivals last year representing an impressive 40% year-over-year increase. Vietnam is targeting 23 million tourists in 2025, a 28% climb from 2019’s figure and a 31% rise year over year.

In Vietnam and across Southeast Asia, the makeup of tourists is changing. With China’s overall outbound international travel still around 80% of its 2019 peak and its GDP growth slowing, another source market is rising to fill the gap: India, where outbound international flight capacity has already surged to 110% of the 2019 level.

For Thailand, this new source of tourists means a reprieve from the economic blow of reduced Chinese travel. For other parts of Southeast Asia, where Chinese travel is surging alongside Indian travel, it represents a double-shot of economic input.

But in all these places, businesses and the public are going to need to get used to a new mix of tourists — and the new spending patterns that go with it.

China’s travel rebound is playing out differently across Southeast Asia, but flight capacity between China and the region is still only 77% of what it was in 2019. Thailand was once China’s most popular overseas destination, but that title belongs to Japan now.

The big Buddha statues are seen at Wat Phra That Pha Sorn Kaew temple, Khao Kho district, Phetchabun province, Thailand, in December 2024.   © Reuters

China’s economic expansion has slowed, with real GDP growth coming in at 5% in 2024 compared to pre-pandemic levels of 6% or higher. Its increasingly well-traveled outbound tourists are also looking for new adventures.

Thailand is targeting 40 million tourists in 2025, up from 35.5 million in 2024. If it can achieve this, it will top 2019’s 39 million arrivals for the first time since the pandemic. But it must do so with less help from Chinese visitors, who in 2019 made up 28% of tourist arrivals but in 2024 accounted for 18.9%. Flight capacity between mainland China and Thailand remains 35% lower than in 2019, suggesting arrivals won’t rise sharply soon.

To encourage mutual tourism, China entered reciprocal visa-free travel agreements with Thailand, Malaysia and Singapore in 2023 and early 2024. Last year, Malaysia’s arrivals from China reached 105% of 2019’s level while Singapore’s were at 85%, with Chinese people representing the largest and highest-spending segment.

Thailand’s arrivals from China were just 61% of the 2019 level, albeit with more overall visitors than its neighbors: 6.73 million, compared with 3.29 for Malaysia and 3.08 for Singapore.

India is rising to challenge China as Southeast Asia’s single-largest source market. New flights and easier visas have ushered in huge increases in Indian arrivals to Malaysia, Thailand and Vietnam, with India’s strong economic growth (6.4% projected in the 2024-2025 financial year) offering a tailwind.

Indians are expected to shell out around $120 billion annually on outbound tourism by 2035, according to Capital Economics, which would make them the fourth-biggest spenders globally — behind the U.S., China and Germany.

Thailand and Malaysia have introduced visa-free arrivals for Indian visitors following the pandemic and have seen arrivals from the subcontinent rise from 2019 by 7% and 54%, respectively. Bangkok has overtaken Dubai as the most popular city destination for Indian travelers.

The most dramatic increase has been in Vietnam, where new nonstop routes have been introduced since 2022, leading to a 363% increase in Indian arrivals in 2024 from 2019.

Chinese arrivals in Vietnam, by comparison, were only 65% of their 2019 level. But Vietnam’s meteoric rise continues, driven by India and a growing mix of other international arrivals led by South Korea.

A slowing economy isn’t the only contributor to Chinese tourists’ changing travel. Mastercard’s data shows they are increasingly interested in new experiences and destinations. We see 9.5% of outbound tourism spend from Chinese travelers on experiences and nightlife. Indians, meanwhile, tend spend more on shopping.

Many Chinese travelers have already been to Southeast Asia and are keen to go further afield. Evidencing this, 2024 traffic on China-Egypt and China-Central Asia routes was more than double that of 2019.

Many Indian travelers may be taking their first international trip as members of the country’s growing middle class. Southeast Asia represents an easy first foray. Looser visa requirements are significant: The Indian passport offers visa-free entry to 56 places worldwide, according to the Henley Passport Index. China’s offers 83.

For first-time travelers, ease, safety and cultural sensitivity are paramount. Many Indians follow specialized diets and the availability of appropriate food ranks high among their travel concerns. Like all tourists, they also want to use payment methods they already understand and feel confident in their physical and financial safety.

Thailand, which has historically welcomed Indian tourists, has for years offered Indian food at its major tourist destinations. Malaysia, home to a large Indian population, has a built-in ability to welcome these new arrivals. Vietnam is working to ensure its new tourists can eat and shop in the style and at the price point they seek.

The changing face of tourism in Southeast Asia should help diversify the tourist trade, lending stability to this vital economic pillar. Don’t expect Chinese characters to disappear from menus and hotel lobbies — but look for more Devanagari text alongside them.
summary: Vietnam's meteoric tourism rise continues, driven by India and a growing mix of other international arrivals led by South Korea. Southeast Asia adapts as outbound Chinese travel remains below pre-pand...

title: Xiaomi lives up to ‘Tesla killer’ nickname, a year since SU7 launch
content:
Chinese smartphone maker balances core ops with meteoric growth in EVs

GUANGZHOU — Xiaomi’s SU7 electric vehicle has overtaken the Tesla Model 3 in Chinese sales a year after its release, turning the company into a rising star in EVs even as it continues to log solid growth in its mainstay smartphone business.

Earlier in March, Samsung Electronics Chairman Lee Jae-yong met with Xiaomi CEO Lei Jun at the latter’s EV factory in Beijing. Local media reported that Samsung, Xiaomi’s major rival on smartphones, was exploring cooperation with the Chinese company as it expands its footprint in electric vehicles.

Xiaomi is building a second EV plant close by. It also plans to launch a sport utility vehicle this year toward the goal of more than doubling overall deliveries from 2024 to 350,000 units.

Around 186,000 SU7s have been sold in China since April 2024, outpacing the Tesla Model 3, according to a Chinese auto data provider. Though the basic SU7 starts at 215,900 yuan ($29,700) to the Model 3’s 235,500 yuan, it has a longer driving range, at 700 kilometers to 634 km, as well as a faster acceleration time from zero to 100 kph, at 5.28 seconds to 6.1 seconds.

The top-end SU7 also outperforms its Model 3 counterpart, despite being around 10% cheaper.

Xiaomi will launch the YU7 electric sport utility vehicle later this year. (Photo from Lei Jun’s social media feed)

Xiaomi’s competitiveness on price is made possible by extensive Chinese supply chains, as well as talent brought in from different industries. Lei said the company’s entry into EVs required people from different backgrounds, and that the only saving grace was that everybody spoke Chinese.

As a smartphone maker, Xiaomi also has strength in software. The basic SU7 comes with navigate on autopilot (NOA) capabilities for highways, while the two higher-end options come with NOA including for city streets. By comparison, the BMW i3 and Porsche Taycan have no NOA capacity, despite their significantly higher price tag.

Xiaomi is boosting the capabilities of vehicles it has already sold as well through over-the-air software updates. It launched autopilot functionality for city streets for its two higher-end options at 10 Chinese cities in June 2024, and expanded nationwide in October. Meanwhile, Tesla began testing city autopilot in China in February, but has since suspended the rollout to address safety issues.

Xiaomi has its eyes on the luxury market as well. On Feb. 27, it launched the SU7 Ultra electric sportscar, which can go from zero to 100 kph in two seconds — faster than the Porsche Taycan Turbo S at a third of the price tag. Orders hit Xiaomi’s annual goal of 10,000 units in just two hours.

But where Xiaomi truly stands out is its ability to grow its existing businesses, including smartphones and electronics, while expanding into EVs. The company logged record groupwide revenues and net profit in 2024, and increased its liquid assets by 28% to 175.1 billion yuan.

This marked Xiaomi’s strongest-ever financial results, Lei posted on social media after full-year earnings were announced on March 18.

Xiaomi branched into EVs after it was blacklisted by the U.S. in 2021, casting a shadow over its smartphone operations. (Photo by Tomoki Mera)

Other automakers have not been as successful. Volkswagen’s net profit dropped 33% last year to 10.72 billion euros ($11.6 billion) amid rising costs and falling Chinese sales. Nissan Motor is seen logging an 80 billion yen ($533 million) net loss for the year ending Monday.

It is unclear when Xiaomi’s EV business will become profitable, given factors like investments into its second plant, according to President Lu Weibing. But the goal does not appear too far off. While Xiaomi’s EV and related operations suffered a 6.2 billion net loss for all of 2024, quarterly losses have continued to shrink.

Xiaomi’s success is unusual even among Chinese EV makers. Xiaopeng sold 190,000 vehicles and reported a 5.5 billion yuan net loss in 2024, 10 years after its founding.

Moving forward, Xiaomi aims to build a smart “Human x Car x Home” ecosystem. The company’s EVs are equipped with the same HyperOS as its smartphones, allowing drivers to access music subscriptions or operate home appliances from their cars’ control panels, for example.

Xiaomi plans to generate further synergies between its smartphones, appliances and EVs. The company aims to expand its network of smartphone and appliance retailers by 30% by the end of the year to up to 20,000 locations, including up to 400 that also sell EVs.

Lei first decided to expand Xiaomi into EVs after the U.S. sanctioned the company in January 2021, raising concerns that chip supply restrictions could impact its smartphone business. The company announced that March that it would invest $10 billion into EVs over 10 years. It plans to eventually expand overseas as well.

On Tuesday, Xiaomi said it will raise over $5 billion through a top-up placement that amounts to 3% of its outstanding shares. Its stock price has since fallen around 10% on concerns of a stock dilution. But it remains up roughly 50% from the beginning of the year, reflecting high hopes for the company among investors.
summary: Xiaomi founder and CEO Lei Jun launches the SU7 Ultra, which can accelerate faster than Porsche's Taycan Turbo S at a third of the price tag, in Beijing on Feb. 27.  © Reuters Chinese smartp...

title: Myanmar-Thailand earthquake: At least 154 dead as rescue efforts underway
content:
90 trapped in collapsed Bangkok building that had been under construction

BANGKOK/CHIANG MAI, Thailand — A 7.7-magnitude earthquake centered northwest of Mandalay, Myanmar, left 144 people dead and 732 injured in the war-ravaged country, and caused at least 10 deaths and damage in the Thai capital more than 1,000 kilometers away.

The earthquake, which was 10 kilometers deep, struck at 12:50 p.m. local time or 1:20 p.m. in Thailand, according to the U.S. Geological Survey, 17 kilometers north of Myanmar’s second largest city. The USGS reported a 6.4-magnitude aftershock 12 minutes after the initial tremor.

Myanmar’s military regime leader. Senior General Min Aung Hlaing, said 144 people had been killed and 732 injured but that these figures were expected to rise. Most of the dead were in the capital Naypyitaw, with others in Sagaing and Kyaukse — near Mandalay.

He issued a rare appeal for international aid and called for people to donate blood at hospitals in the affected areas, notably Sagaing, Mandalay and Naypyitaw.

“I declared a state of emergency in all affected areas and opened a path for international support,” he said on the evening TV news. “I recently agreed and accepted an offer from the ASEAN Coordinating Center for Humanitarian Assistance and India to send aid tomorrow. I call on any countries, any organization and the public in Myanmar to support us.”

Marie Manrique, Program Coordinator for the International Federation of the Red Cross, said to reporters in Geneva, via video link from Yangon, Myanmar’s biggest city: “Public infrastructure has been damaged, including roads, bridges and public buildings. We currently have concerns for large-scale dams that people are watching to see the conditions of.”

Local media showed Min Aung Hlaing inspecting areas affected by the earthquake in Naypyitaw.

Myanmar has been wracked by civil war since the generals seized power in February 2021. Previous military regimes have been reluctant to accept international aid after natural disasters, such as following Cyclone Nargis in 2008.

One woman in Mandalay, which has a population of 1.5 million, who did not want to give her name, said: “Many buildings have collapsed, and I’m unable to contact my family in Sagaing. The phone lines are also out of service.”

A man in the city added that several buildings around the palace had been destroyed and a colonial-era bridge connecting Mandalay with neighboring Sagaing collapsed into a river.

A resident of Yangon, Myanmar’s largest city, said he was unable to reach his family in Mandalay. “I’m worrying so much for my family. My parents are living in a very old building in Mandalay.”

The opposition National Unity Government issued a statement pledging to stand with the public throughout the recovery and rebuilding process. It added that it was compiling reports on casualties and damage while conducting search and rescue operations, relocation efforts, and reconstruction activities.

It also urged the international community to provide humanitarian aid and effective “coordination to ensure that aid reaches those genuinely in need.”

In Bangkok, a partially built 30-floor State Audit Office building in the Chatuchak district collapsed, leaving at least five people dead. Videos posted online showed construction workers fleeing the site. Some 600 rescuers worked into the night to try to free around 90 trapped people. At least 12 had been rescued four hours later.

The collapsed building was near Chatuchak Market, a large outdoor bazaar popular among foreign tourists.

By midnight, 10 were dead, 16 injured and 10 missing across three construction sites in Bangkok. The death toll included the operator of a crane that fell over in the Din Daeng district.

Skyscrapers elsewhere in the Thai capital swayed as workers, residents and tourists evacuated office buildings, hotels, condominiums and embassies. water from rooftop swimming pools on high rise buildings cascaded down to the ground.

A collapsed building is seen in Mandalay, Myanmar, after an earthquake struck the Southeast Asian country on March 28.

The Stock Exchange of Thailand suspended all trading activities at 2 p.m. All stations of the Bangkok Mass Transit System (BTS) Skytrain and the underground Metropolitan Rapid Transit system were closed.

Thai Prime Minister Paetongtarn Shinawatra, speaking from the southern city of Phuket, declared Bangkok an emergency zone. She later said all the city’s public parks would remain open all night for people to take shelter. The Bangkok government distributed food and water and deployed mobile toilets.

As the night set in, stranded people — most already inured to lengthy commutes — took shelter in cool lobbies and ground floor cafes and restaurants. Others sat along pavements and in ground floor restaurants, at bus stops with no buses in sight and in occasional green areas. Many motorcycles carried three people. An exhausted taxi driver told of a nearly five-hour journey that covered less than two kilometers.

Major tech suppliers and automotive manufacturers said they had suffered little disruption from the quake. Delta Electronics said its production line suspended operations for an hour and then resumed manufacturing. KINPO, Quanta and Lite all reported their lines were not affected.

Nissan Motor stopped production to evacuate employees at its plant east of Bangkok. Honda’s production plant in Ayutthaya, north of Bangkok, resumed production after stopping temporarily. Toyota’s Gateway plant continued to operate as usual. Bangkok’s airports were unaffected.

No deaths or injuries were reported in the northern Thai provinces of Chiang Mai and Chiang Rai even though they were much closer to the epicenter.

The quake was also felt in southwest China and Vietnam.
summary: Rescuers work at the site of a collapsed building in Bangkok after tremors from a strong earthquake that struck central Myanmar on March 28 caused the building in the Thai capital to crumble. (Photo b...

title: Japan automakers send more cars to U.S. from Mexico ahead of tariffs
content:
Shipments jump 17% amid rush to build up inventories

TOKYO — Japanese automakers have been exporting more Mexican-built vehicles to the U.S. in recent months, apparently aiming to bulk up inventories ahead of the Trump administration’s latest tariffs.

The companies sent 217,000 vehicles to the U.S. from Mexico between December and February, based on data from industry intelligence firm MarkLines — up 17% from a year earlier.

The increase came amid threats by U.S. President Donald Trump to impose heavier tariffs on auto imports. He announced this past Wednesday a 25% tariff on foreign-made vehicles, starting April 3.

Honda Motor’s exports increased 4% to 43,000 units for the three-month period. The company builds the relatively low-priced HR-V sport utility vehicle in Mexico, of which it exported 170,000 to the U.S. throughout 2024, accounting for more than 10% of its U.S. auto sales volume.

The economic impact of the new auto tariffs on Honda, including those targeting Canada, is expected to amount to 700 billion yen ($4.7 billion). The company has been moving to soften the blow.

Shinji Aoyama, a Honda executive vice president who serves as risk management officer, said in February that the company would try to send Mexican- and Canadian-built vehicles to the U.S. earlier — possibly that month — ahead of the tariffs.

Toyota Motor, which builds the Tacoma pickup truck in Mexico, saw the largest increase in exports from the country to the U.S. among Japanese automakers. They came to 64,000 units for the three months ended February — 3.7 times the year-earlier level.

The jump owes mainly to a lower baseline in late 2023 and early 2024, when Toyota halted Mexican production to switch to new models.

“There is strong demand for cars in the U.S.,” said Seiji Sugiura, senior analyst at the Tokai Tokyo Intelligence Laboratory. “Given the Trump tariffs, [automakers] were likely conscious of a need to build up inventory.”

The Trump administration plans to adjust the duty on tariff-free vehicles imported from Canada and Mexico under the United States-Mexico-Canada Agreement. The changes would be based on the percentage of U.S.-made parts used in the vehicles.

This would put pressure on Japanese automakers to reorganize their North American production networks.

The auto tariffs announced this week will ultimately lead to “higher prices, fewer options for consumers, and fewer manufacturing jobs in the U.S.,” said Jennifer Safavian, president and CEO of Autos Drive America, in a statement. The group consists of a dozen non-U.S. automakers with American operations.
summary: The volume of Honda HR-Vs exported to the U.S. from Mexico accounted for 10% of Honda Motor's U.S. sales volume last year. (Honda) Shipments jump 17% amid rush to build up inventories SHOYA ...

title: SoftBank Group eyes $1tn U.S. plan for AI robot industrial parks
content:
Tech investor expects automation to help understaffed American manufacturers

TOKYO/LONDON — SoftBank Group is looking to create industrial parks across the U.S. featuring artificial intelligence-equipped factories, Nikkei has learned.

The Japanese tech investor could commit to about $1 trillion in such investments, significantly more than the $500 billion AI infrastructure investment that billionaire CEO Masayoshi Son announced at the White House in January with OpenAI CEO Sam Altman and Oracle’s Larry Ellison.

Son is preparing to visit the U.S. and may soon announce his latest megaproject with the Trump administration.

With the growth of the U.S. workforce predicted to slow, SoftBank is confident that using AI robots will help American manufacturing stay competitive.

The factories could use humanoid robots that can walk autonomously. The group is considering procuring graphics processing units from Nvidia and may introduce technology from German robotics company Agile Robots, sources said. SoftBank Group’s Vision Fund has invested in Agile Robots.

Among potential partner manufacturers is Taiwanese company Foxconn, sources said. SoftBank Group aims to reduce human involvement by employing AI in production processes for a wide range of products, such as smartphones, cars, servers and air conditioners.

Foxconn, also known as Hon Hai Precision Industry, has partnered with SoftBank Group before. The Taiwanese company served as the manufacturer for the Pepper robot, and it is expected to be the sole supplier of servers for the Stargate AI infrastructure project with ChatGPT developer OpenAI.

For the industrial parks, SoftBank Group intends to use a form of project financing backed by equipment usage fees, similar to the AI data centers proposed for the Stargate project.

It is also likely to tap financing from banks and investment funds. Middle Eastern money is a promising source, possibly including Abu Dhabi-based tech investor MGX and Saudi Arabia’s Public Investment Fund. The Saudi Arabian government and SoftBank Group are already working on a joint robotics venture.

But the Stargate project is still a work in progress. SoftBank Group’s plan is to invest 10% to 20% of the capital with three other companies and finance the rest. It is unclear whether the framework can be set before locations are selected and construction of the facilities begins.

The industrial park plan would have an even larger scale, leaving questions about whether SoftBank Group would be able to secure partner manufacturers and funding.

Son has repeatedly changed SoftBank Group’s focus in line with technological advances, from internet sites to mobile phones to tech investment. It now aims to become the world’s largest AI group and is planning to invest tens of billions of dollars in OpenAI.
summary: SoftBank Group CEO Masayoshi Son makes a presentation at a meeting with Japanese companies in Tokyo on Feb. 3. (Photo by Yutaka Miyaguchi) Tech investor expects automation to help understaffed Am...

title: Sumitomo Realty to pump $17bn into Tokyo, Mumbai properties
content:
Japan developer raises guidance as office, hotel and condo rates soar

TOKYO — Japan’s Sumitomo Realty & Development will invest 2.5 trillion yen ($16.6 billion) in projects in Tokyo and India, with the aim of boosting pretax profit by half to over 400 billion yen in a decade, the company announced on Friday.

Sumitomo Realty will spend 500 billion yen on a mixed-use development in Mumbai, and 2 trillion yen on large-scale redevelopment projects in the Roppongi and Yaesu districts of Tokyo over 10 years through March 2035.

Though rising construction costs in Japan are pushing many developers to tap the brakes on redevelopment plans, Sumitomo Realty sees a decline in new office space leading to a tighter supply and more business opportunities.

In its business plan through the year ending March 2028, the company aims to achieve a three-year cumulative pretax profit of 900 billion yen and net profit of 650 billion yen. It will also proceed with the sale of cross-shareholdings.

The developer expects to raise dividends 10 yen a share per year during the three years. Investments and dividends will be covered by operating cash flow.

The announcement comes after U.S. hedge fund Elliott Investment Management, an activist investor, acquired shares in Sumitomo Realty.

Sumitomo Realty Managing Executive Officer Tokiyuki Okada argued that shareholders benefit from the company’s business model of holding on to the properties it develops rather than selling them.

“If the company continues to invest, it will be a win-win situation in that we can share bigger fruits with shareholders,” Okada told Nikkei. 

Also on Friday, Sumitomo Realty raised its net profit guidance for the year ending Monday by 1 billion yen from its earlier forecast to 191 billion yen, up 8% on the year.

Sales are now expected to increase 4% to 1.01 trillion yen, an upgrade of 10 billion yen. The company cited rising office rents, hotel room rates and condominium sales prices for the upgrades.
summary: Sumitomo Realty is focusing on large-scale redevelopment projects in Tokyo. (Sumitomo Realty & Development) Japan developer raises guidance as office, hotel and condo rates soar NAOYUKI TOYAM...

title: Trump’s trade adviser sees automakers reopening shuttered U.S. plants
content:
Navarro says there will be no downturn for companies through tariffs

WASHINGTON — President Donald Trump’s new 25% tariffs on all automobiles imported to the U.S. will not result in a period of downturn for auto companies and there are paths they can take to avoid the levies without massive new investment, his senior counselor for trade and manufacturing told CNBC on Friday morning.

“The answer is absolutely not,” Peter Navarro said, when asked if companies will suffer multiyear periods of depressed profit margins as they slowly move production to the U.S.

“The key stat here is the low capacity utilization in the U.S. auto industry. It’s down in the 60s,” he said, meaning that there is “plenty of room to ramp up quickly the kind of production we need.”

By increasing the utilization rate, by 25 or 30 points, “that won’t create any inflation. It’ll just create prosperity,” he emphasized.

If, for instance, American factories were running at 95% utilization, the situation would have been “totally different,” he said.

Navarro told the show that moving production to the U.S. is not necessarily limited to greenfield investment, such as opening new factories. There will also be “brownfield” investment, he said, referring to purchasing or leasing existing facilities.

“Throughout the Midwest, there’s shuttered factories that can be easily reopened,” he explained.

Navarro added that there are national security aspects in Trump’s auto tariffs. He said the auto industry was part of the “Arsenal of Democracy” that won World War II. American auto companies made jeeps, tanks and trucks and the Allies would not have been able to prevail without the “might” of the American industry, he said.

He lamented the current state of the U.S. auto sector as nothing but an assembly shop for parts that come from the rest of the world. The majority of the most valuable components of a car — such as the engine, transmission and drivetrain — come from countries like Germany and Japan, he said.

“So, what President Trump wants to do is bring that back,” he added.

But shares of America’s Big Three automakers — General Motors, Ford Motor and Stellantis, formerly Chrysler — have dropped over 13%, 6% and 8%, respectively, in the past two days, reflecting the market’s lack of confidence in the Trump administration’s economic policy.

Yet, Navarro’s explanation is in line with the rejection of globalization that Vice President JD Vance laid out in a speech this month.

Vance told the American Dynamism conference in Washington that past U.S. trade policy had “two conceits” about globalization — the belief that design and manufacturing could be separated, and that cheap labor was beneficial.

Vance called cheap labor “a drug” that companies have become addicted to and that shipping manufacturing overseas was an easy alternative to investing in innovation.

Trump is “dead serious” about bringing jobs back to the U.S., the vice president said.
summary: Senior trade adviser Peter Navarro speaks next to U.S. President Donald Trump in the Oval Office on Feb. 13.  Navarro says there will be no downturn for companies through tari...

title: Mitsui Sumitomo Insurance to buy 15% of BlackRock-backed W. R. Berkley
content:
Japan group seeks expertise in growing specialty insurance field

TOKYO — Japan’s Mitsui Sumitomo Insurance said Friday it will spend $3.8 billion to acquire a 15% stake in U.S. insurer W. R. Berkley in a bid to tap into the growing specialty insurance market.

The Japanese property insurer aims to finish the share purchase by the end of March 2026. It will appoint one director to W. R. Berkley’s board.

W. R. Berkley is a Fortune 500 company strong in liability insurance for corporate executives, among other specialty lines. Mitsui Sumitomo looks to gain know-how in specialty insurance and improve product development and risk assessment.

In the U.S., the market for general insurance products is expected to grow 8% to 9% a year, but specialty insurance is seen rising more than 10%. Specialty insurance, which also covers events like cyberattacks, tends to produce stable earnings, since it is less exposed to natural disasters.

W. R. Berkley, founded in 1967 and headquartered in the U.S. state of Connecticut, saw net premiums written climb 9% last year to over $11.9 billion. Consolidated net profit rose 27% to $1.7 billion. It counts global asset management leader BlackRock as a shareholder.

MS&AD Insurance Group Holdings, the parent company of Mitsui Sumitomo Insurance, reported a group adjusted profit of 379.9 billion yen ($2.53 billion) for the fiscal year ended March 2024. Overseas business accounted for 139.5 billion yen, or about 37%, of that figure.

Other Japanese nonlife insurance companies have also made acquisitions in the specialty field. Tokio Marine Holdings purchased U.S.-based HCC Insurance Holdings for $7.5 billion in 2015. Sompo Holdings acquired U.S. player Endurance Specialty Holdings, now Sompo International, for $6.3 billion about two years later.
summary: Overseas businesses now account for nearly 40% of the profit at the Mitsui Sumitomo Insurance group. (Photo by Natsumi Iwata) Japan group seeks expertise in growing specialty insurance field JUN ...

title: Ajinomoto to invest $165m to boost production of chip materials
content:
Japan biotech company utilized amino acid know-how to create film for GPUs, CPUs

TOKYO — Ajinomoto will invest at least 25 billion yen ($166 million) by 2030 to increase production capacity for a semiconductor material by 50%, aiming to cultivate areas outside its core food business to solidify its revenue base.

The Japanese food and biotech company will increase production capacity for Ajinomoto Build-up Film (ABF), an insulating material used in the latest graphics processing units for data centers as well as central processing units of computers and other devices.

The company’s market share in the data center and CPU fields exceeds 95%. The film was created by applying insulating plastic technology using amino-acid-related expertise to computer semiconductor substrates. Ajinomoto’s roots lie in its research into amino acids for use in seasonings.

ABF is produced at subsidiary Ajinomoto Fine-Techno’s facilities in Gunma prefecture, northwest of Tokyo, and in the city of Kawasaki. The company has already invested 25 billion yen over two years through the current fiscal year, which ends Monday, to expand its facilities.

“We will invest the same amount or more by 2030 as demand increases,” said President Shigeo Nakamura in an interview with Nikkei. “We are also exploring establishing new bases,” he added, indicating that the focus in on Japan.

Ajinomoto’s functional materials operations, which include ABF, accounted for 20% of its total business profit in the year ended March 2024. The company is projecting a 35% profit increase for functional materials to 37.2 billion yen in the current year.

Nakamura took over as president in February, having previously worked in the research field, and led the development and growth of the electronics materials business.

“We expect sales of electronics materials, mainly ABF, to grow at an annual rate of more than 10% through 2030,” he said. “We will continue to meet needs by evolving ABF to a more highly functional form that supports high-performance semiconductors in the long term.”
summary: Ajinomoto President Shigeo Nakamura said the company is exploring building new plants for chip materials. (Photo by Yukinori Okamura) Japan biotech company utilized amino acid know-how to cr...

title: KKR and state-backed JIC to take Japan’s Topcon private for $2.3bn
content:
Deal for medical gear maker marks first time JIC teams up with global private equity firm

TOKYO (Reuters) — U.S.-based private equity firm KKR and Japanese state-backed fund Japan Investment Corp (JIC) will acquire medical gear maker Topcon in a tender offer buyout worth 348 billion yen ($2.3 billion), KKR said on Friday.

Private equity deals in Japan have been booming as corporate governance reforms and increasingly vocal activist shareholders push more companies to go private.

KKR will invest around 256 billion yen to take a majority stake and JIC’s private equity arm will invest around 95 billion yen for a minority interest.

Takashi Eto, Topcon president and chief executive, will sell his shares in the tender offer and then reinvest in the buyout. Currently he holds 0.07% of Topcon’s shares, filings showed.

It is the first time that JIC, which is overseen by Japan’s trade ministry, has teamed up with a global private equity firm, a JIC spokesperson said.

The transaction is the latest in a wave of take-private deals among Japanese companies that follow in the wake of activist investor pressure.

Topcon’s two largest investors are both activists — ValueAct Capital and Oasis Management — holding stakes of 13.69% and 10.58%, respectively, based on LSEG data.

“We want to pursue our long-term strategies for eye-care products and positioning businesses by going private as it’s difficult to do so when shareholders, including activist investors, are asking us to achieve profits and higher share prices in the relatively short term,” Topcon’s managing executive officer, Yoshikuni Ito, said.

The tender offer price of 3,300 yen per share marks a 5.4% premium on Topcon’s closing price of 3,130 yen on Friday and a 99.5% premium over the simple average closing price of Topcon’s stock for the 12 months up to Dec. 9, 2024, KKR said.

A future relisting is in the offing but not for at least four years, in order to allow management time to execute its strategy, Ito said.

Other privatizations following activist involvement include chemicals company JSR and software developer Fuji Soft, which was acquired in January by KKR after a protracted bidding war with rival private equity group Bain Capital.

“KKR and JIC are great partners to help Topcon strengthen its competitiveness and achieve its potential,” Rob Hale, co-CEO of ValueAct Capital, said in a statement.
summary: Topcon's two largest investors are both activists, ValueAct Capital and Oasis Management. (Photo by Takuro Hosoda) Deal for medical gear maker marks first time JIC teams up with global priva...

title: Rohingya refugees in Bangladesh welcome $73m in new U.S. aid
content:
Move eases food fears for more than 1m people after Trump slashed aid budget

COX’S BAZAR, Bangladesh (AP) — The U.S. government has confirmed it would provide $73 million in new financial aid for Rohingya refugees through the United Nations’ food agency, easing worries among more than 1 million refugees that essential food rations would be cut.

Aid agencies, the U.N. and refugees have voiced concerns after the World Food Program warned it may be affected after U.S. President Donald Trump’s administration announced it was cutting international aid.

The World Food Program said earlier this month that if it is not able to raise funds, it will have no option but to halve food rations to $6 a month from previous $12.50 in Bangladesh’s southern coastal district of Cox’s Bazar, where the Rohingya live in sprawling camps.

The Bangladesh government’s Refugee, Relief and Repatriation Commissioner, Mohammed Mizanur Rahman, told reporters that he received confirmation from the WFP on Thursday that refugees in Cox’s Bazar — as well as the thousands who have been relocated to Bhashan Char island — will continue to receive $12 to $13 a month each in aid.

“This food and nutrition support through WFP will provide critically needed food and nutrition assistance for more than one million people,” U.S. State Department spokesperson Tammy Bruce said in a post on X, formerly Twitter, on Thursday.

“It is important that our international partners engage with sharing the burden with life-saving assistance such as this,” Bruce added.

The U.S. had been the largest provider of aid to the Rohingya refugees, contributing nearly $2.4 billion since 2017 and providing the U.N. with emergency food and nutrition assistance, according to the State Department. The U.S. provided about $300 million in humanitarian aid for the Rohingya in 2024.

Refugees in Cox’s Bazar welcomed the announcement that aid will continue.

“I am glad that the President of America is donating the money, which will help (provide food) our grandchildren. We are very happy,” said 60-year-old Hussain Bahar.

Forid Alam, a 36-year-old refugee at Balukhali Rohingya refugee camp, said the announcement was a gift coming days before Muslims’ largest festival Eid al-Fitr.

“We are grateful to the people of Bangladesh, its government, and the donors who are donating. We are so thrilled after hearing the news ahead of Eid that we don’t have words to express our gratitude. We are praying from the bottom of our hearts and are truly glad,” he said.

U.N. Secretary General Antonio Guterres, who visited Bangladesh recently, said Cox’s Bazar is “ground zero for the impact of the budget cuts on people in desperate need.”

Hundreds of thousands of Rohingya reside in Bangladesh, including more than 700,000 who arrived in 2017 fleeing persecution in Myanmar. About 70,000 others crossed the border from Myanmar in 2024 when, during fighting with the military junta, the opposition force known as the Arakan Army effectively took over Rakhine state where Rohingya were displaced.

Bangladesh says repatriation of the refugees to Myanmar is the ultimate solution, but complexities over verification and other diplomatic and political issues have made the refugees’ return uncertain.
summary: Rohingya refugees in Cox's Bazar, Bangladesh, have welcomed the announcement that U.S. food aid will continue. © AP Move eases food fears for more than 1m people after Trump slashed aid budget March 2...

title: Uncertainty awaits U.S. companies reliant on tariffed goods
content:
With duties seen eating into margins, businesses strategize mitigation measures

NEW YORK — With U.S. President Donald Trump’s tariff plans well underway, the only sure thing for American companies heavily reliant on cheap imports is uncertainty, based on their earnings reports and projections for the year ahead.

Businesses like low-cost retailers and apparel manufacturers are projecting declining revenues for the year ahead as consumer confidence weakens amidst persistent inflation and recessionary fears. At the same time, tariffs are eating into profit margins and are forcing companies to consider mitigation strategies from supply chain tweaks to price increases.

These choices will be further complicated next week as new reciprocal tariffs are expected to be announced on April 2. And partially implemented tariffs on China, Canada and Mexico remain in flux.

“There’s still a great deal of uncertainty as to what complete hits, how those change. April 2 is a big day in terms of reciprocal tariffs, and so our teams are actively looking to mitigate” said Dollar Tree CEO Michael Creedon Jr. on the company earnings call Wednesday.

Apparel company Lululemon beat revenue expectations when it announced earnings Thursday, but it projects a 100 basis point decline in operating margin on the year, mostly attributable to tariffs on China and Mexico.

Trump has levied a number of tariffs since returning to the White House in January, including a 10% tariff on all Chinese goods in early February that increased to 20% on March 4, the same day 25% tariffs on all Canadian and Mexican goods went into effect — though a significant portion of goods have been exempt so far.

On top of the unannounced reciprocal tariffs, an additional 25% tariff on automobiles is set to take effect April 2.

Many companies have not included Trump’s second round of tariffs into their guidance due to a lack of clarity on timing and scope.

Dollar Tree — a major chain of discount variety stores — said they had been able to mitigate roughly 90% of the expected hit by the initial 10% levy on Chinese goods, which would have cost them roughly $15 million to $20 million each month.

“We put actions in place as soon as November,” Creedon said, including tweaking manufacturing, negotiating with suppliers, and increasing prices when necessary.

The company will use a similar approach for the increased tariff on China and those on Canada and Mexico, but it could not say how effective it will be in curbing the $20 million per month the new tariffs are projected to cost them.

Trump’s first term and the COVID-19 pandemic led many companies, including Dollar Tree, toward a so-called China plus one strategy that seeks to diversify supply chains and reduce reliance on the country.

But other companies with more direct manufacturing in China may not be able to be as nimble. For shoe and apparel giant Nike, 22% of its factories and 30% of its materials facilities are in China.

Last week, the company reported a much-worse-than-expected decline in sales and projected a drop in gross margins in the quarter ahead, in large part due to tariffs on imports from China and Mexico.

In addition to cutting into margins for the businesses themselves, tariffs are adding onto the already souring recession fears and inflationary concerns that are causing consumers to cut back on spending.

“As we enter 2025, we are not anticipating improvement in the microenvironmental, particularly for our core customer,” said CEO Todd Vasos of Dollar General, the leading U.S. low-cost variety store, on the company’s earnings call this month.

“We believe that it’s going to get even more fluid with some of the tariffs,” he said. “So we’re watching that very closely as we move through the upcoming weeks.”
summary: Dollar Tree and other U.S. discount variety store chains are wary about the impact of U.S. tariffs on imports. © Reuters With duties seen eating into margins, businesses strategize mitigation measures...

title: CK Hutchison faces crunch time as ports sale overshadows China business
content:
As state media attacks, analysts say scuttling deal would prove Trump's Panama point

HONG KONG — CK Hutchison Holdings is approaching a moment of truth for its deal to sell dozens of global port assets, including two at the Panama Canal, to a consortium led by U.S. investment fund BlackRock.

The Hong Kong-based conglomerate controlled by tycoon Li Ka-shing’s family is expected to sign “definitive documentation” with the consortium by next Wednesday. But since it struck the deal in early March — in the wake of U.S. President Donald Trump’s vows to wrest control of the Panama Canal away from China — the company has come under relentless criticism from Chinese state media, prompting speculation about the fate of the agreement.

The attacks, which portray the transaction as unpatriotic and contrary to China’s interests, continued Friday. The latest edition of Ta Kung Pao — a Hong Kong-based newspaper controlled by Beijing that has spearheaded the campaign against the sale — included a story headlined, “Only by crossing the river together with the state, businesspeople gain respect.” The article cited various pro-Beijing figures as well as ordinary “citizens” who expressed views that safeguarding security and state interests should be the priority.

Several of Ta Kung Pao’s articles on the matter have been reposted in full by the joint official website of the Chinese Communist Party’s Hong Kong and Macao Work Office and the central government’s Hong Kong and Macao Affairs Office — implying that the government endorses them. On Wednesday and Thursday, the website reposted articles stressing that businesses will destroy their own foundation if they ignore national interests and must stand with the state against hegemony and bullying.

The intense pressure has cast a shadow over CK Hutchison, all entities in Li Ka-shing’s empire, and the broader Chinese business community. Chinese authorities have instructed state-owned enterprises to halt new deals linked to the Hong Kong-based group, Bloomberg reported on Thursday.

When questioned about this directive on Thursday evening, Xu Yugao, joint company secretary and in-house counsel at CNOOC — a Hong Kong-listed arm of one of China’s three state-owned oil majors — told reporters and analysts that he and many others were “following” the developments surrounding the deal with great interest.

At the same time, he said that business dealings remained “extremely steady” with no “external interfering factors.” Xu was referring to a joint oil exploration project in the South China Sea with the former Husky Energy, once a CK Hutchison company that recently merged with Canadian energy conglomerate Cenovus. While Xu said he was unsure whether its Canadian partner is linked with Li Ka-shing, CK Hutchison’s disclosure indicates that it is an investor in Cenovus.

Ta Kung Pao, a Hong Kong-based daily newspaper controlled by Beijing, has been spearheading the criticism against CK Hutchison’s ports sale. These issues are from the latest three days through Friday. (Photo by Kenji Kawase)

Beyond the sheer geopolitical implications of CK Hutchison selling 43 ports across 23 countries, valued at $22.8 billion, experts say the deal has raised concerns in Beijing about “losing face.” Reports have suggested that Chinese President Xi Jinping was not informed before the announcement, whereas Trump is believed to have been kept in the loop by BlackRock CEO Larry Fink.

“The sale impacts the Belt and Road Initiative and diminishes Chinese influence in America’s backyard,” said Claus Soong, analyst at German think tank MERICS. “Xi Jinping’s image as a strongman is damaged, as Trump now has something to brag about, while Xi wasn’t even consulted before the deal, and Beijing has limited leverage to halt it,” he said.

Louis-Vincent Gave, founding partner and CEO at Gavekal Research, echoed this.

“Beijing has few, if any, legal options to scupper the deal,” Gave said. But if it does go forward, Li Ka-shing and his family business empire “could be seen to have defied Beijing and got away with it. This would be an awkward loss of face for Xi Jinping,” raising questions about future consequences for the family and group.

Gave believes that China is “reminding Hong Kong businesses that Beijing should have a say in important strategic decisions,” and that it still hopes to sink the deal not only by squeezing CK Hutchison “but perhaps by putting pressure on BlackRock,” which has business interests in China as well.

CK Hutchison and BlackRock did not immediately respond to Nikkei Asia’s requests for comments.

Bryan Mercurio, a professor at the Chinese University of Hong Kong specializing in international economic law and bilateral trade agreements, told Nikkei Asia that CK Hutchison could conceivably pull out and compensate BlackRock using a break clause. He argued that CK Hutchison “would have to react accordingly if China pulled internal economic levers,” considering its significant business exposure in China, despite its diversification over the years.

Yet, Mercurio cautioned that blocking the deal would “serve to confirm Trump’s rhetoric that ‘China’ controlled the port.”

Likewise, he stressed that if Hong Kong authorities were to step in to block the transaction, “it would be an unprecedented move that could reinforce the claims of President Trump and others asserting that Hong Kong’s trade, finance and policies are not entirely independent from China.”

He said that the saga has fewer implications for foreign companies or specific sectors such as finance, but that “other Hong Kong conglomerates would be wise to take notice.”

CNOOC Chairman Wang Dongjin, third from left, designated the state oil company’s in-house legal counsel Xu Yugao, far left, to answer questions regarding CK Hutchison and geopolitical matters during its annual earnings briefing in Hong Kong on March 27. (Photo by Kenji Kawase) 

If nothing else, the drama has illustrated how Chinese and Hong Kong companies cannot easily dodge the superpower rivalry.

Miao Jianmin, chairman of China Merchants Bank, acknowledged at an annual earnings briefing on Thursday that “it is difficult to avoid any influence from geopolitics” when doing business internationally. Miao, who doubles as chairman of China Merchants Group — whose port operating unit is a key conduit for Beijing to pursue harbor assets overseas — said this was especially the case in maritime affairs, shipping and ports.

Miao said geopolitics is the “first thing” his group considers when expanding abroad and stressed that “keeping good communication with the regulating authorities, in order to protect from various risks” is of equal importance.

Additional reporting by Peggy Ye.

title: When glaciers roamed Mars
content: The surface of Mars is known for being an extremely cold, desiccated, and irradiated place. But as its many surface features attest, the red planet was once a warmer, wetter place with flowing water and glaciers. Today, most of the remaining water on the surface is largely confined to its polar regions in the form of ice caps, permafrost, and subsurface glaciers. Nevertheless, the seasonal melting and freezing of this ice still impacts the Martian environment and offers clues about glacial activity in the past.

title: Quantum entanglement reveals strange metals' unique electron behavior at critical point

Now, a team of physicists at Rice University has made a breakthrough in this area using a tool from quantum information science. Their study, published recently in Nature Communications, reveals that electrons in strange metals become more entangled at a crucial tipping point, shedding new light on the behavior of these enigmatic materials. The discovery could pave the way for advances in superconductors with the potential to transform energy use in the future.

title: ‘There’s a dangerous epidemic in boxing’: the tragic, cautionary tale of Paul Bamba
content:
Paul Bamba was ambitious and loved by his friends and family. But his quest for success was built on dubious fights and a fatal disregard for his own health

As 2023 drew to a close, Paul Bamba was a marginal club fighter with a record of five wins and three losses, compiled against mediocre opposition. Then his career changed in a very strange way. Bamba fought 14 times in 2024 and won all 14 of those fights by knockout. On 21 December 2024 he was credited with defeating Rogelio Medina Luna in a fight for the World Boxing Association ‘gold’ cruiserweight championship when Medina quit on his stool after the sixth round.

Bamba was living his dream. But the dream appears to have been a fantasy built in significant measure on fixed fights.

Finally the voice emerges, whispering through your headphones in that familiar rich, reverent Euro-tone, like being spoken to by the sun. This is a voice that says: I am here to command. But I am also just a conduit for a divinity that flows through me and into you. Although mainly, and let’s be absolutely clear, through me.

title: Manchester City enter Last Dance era under Guardiola with FA Cup in sights
content:
Some players’ futures are in doubt but beating Bournemouth could help those they leave behind

Pep Guardiola is a basketball aficionado and has often been seen courtside in America trying to learn from one of the world’s most intense sports. The Manchester City manager holds Michael Jordan in high esteem and it feels as if the next two months may be the club’s version of the basketball legend’s Last Dance documentary for some of their senior players. The FA Cup is the NBA championship for those wondering where they may start next season.

City face a second trip of the season to Bournemouth, where their 32-match unbeaten run ended in November, hoping to reach a semi-final at Wembley for the seventh successive year. Guardiola and his side have barely recovered since losing Rodri, City’s Jordan according to his coach, and a second defeat by Andoni Iraola’s men on Sunday would remove any chance of a trophy for the Spaniard and his ageing charges this season. Jordan was asked for one great final year with the Chicago Bulls. Guardiola, who regards the Club World Cup as the start of the 2025-26 campaign, needs two months from his creaking squad.

title: Fabian Hürzeler appeals to Brighton’s ‘blue heads’ to turn tables on Forest
content:
Borrowing from the All Blacks, manager says the power of psychology has helped his side recover from 7-0 drubbing

Were Fabian Hürzeler in any doubt about the importance of the FA Cup to Brighton fans, he received a gentle reminder when back in his home town of Munich. Hürzeler’s short international break, among family and friends, received a polite but pointed interruption. “Walking through the city, one of the Brighton supporters called my name and said he’s really looking forward to the game,” said the club’s head coach. “He said that we have to give everything in this game, and of course you feel it, but for me it’s important that we don’t make it artificial excitement.”

Hürzeler, born a decade after Albion lost the 1983 final to Manchester United in a replay, can be excused for not knowing the lore of Steve Foster’s headband, Tony Grealish’s hirsute captaincy and the striker Gordon Smith’s “must score” miss. There are always the owner, Tony Bloom, and the club’s time-served staffers to run through the details. In any case, Brighton relived that Wembley day two seasons ago, another hard-luck loss to United in the semi-finals, this time on penalties.

title: Fulham 0-3 Crystal Palace: FA Cup quarter-final – as it happened
content:
Goals from Eberechi Eze, Ismaïla Sarr and Eddie Nketiah saw the Eagles soar into the FA Cup semi-finals

I’d love someone to explain the 12.15pm kick-off time of this game. It’s not like the Sheffield derby or the Old Firm where it’s scheduled early to reduce pre-match drinking, but I guess neither fanbase has too far to travel so it’s far less of a concern than when, say, Bournemouth are given a 12.30pm game away at Newcastle. OK, maybe I don’t have too many gripes after all.

Alysa Liu completed her stunning comeback to competitive figure skating with a world championship title on Friday night in Boston, becoming the first American woman to win the sport’s biggest competition outside the Olympics in nearly two decades.

The 19-year-old from Clovis, California, who vanished from the sport nearly three years ago uncertain if she’d ever return, delivered a spellbinding free skate inside a sold-out TD Garden to dethrone three-time defending champion Kaori Sakamoto of Japan.
